hints.content:
There are $\purpleC6$ pencils in a pack.

There are $\greenD{54}$ total pencils.

[[☃ image 1]]



How many $\blueD{\text{groups}}$ are there?

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths, a first tape labeled 54 and a shorter second tape with one part labeled 6. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the first tape is labeled with a question mark and the words equal groups. !

hints.content:
We can write this as a multiplication problem. 

$\purpleC{\text{size of the group}}\times\blueD{\text{ number of groups}} = \greenD{\text{ total}}$

So, $\purpleC6\times\blueD{\text{?}} = \greenD{54}$

We can also write this as a division problem. 

$\greenD{\text{total}}\div\purpleC{\text{ size of the groups}}=\blueD{\text{ number of groups}} $

So, $\greenD{54}\div \purpleC6=\blueD{\text{?}}$

The equations that would help us find out how many pack of pencils there are:  

 -   $\purpleC6\times\blueD{\text{?}} = \greenD{54}$
 - $\greenD{54}\div \purpleC6=\blueD{\text{?}}$

question.content:
The school store has $54$ pencils to sell.  The store sells all pencils in packs of $6$.  

**Which equations would help us find out how many packs of pencils the store has?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
